Authors: El Hachemi N., Gendreau M., Rousseau L.-M.
Title: Solving a log-truck scheduling problem with constraint programming
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Interuniversity Research Centre on Enterprise Networks, Logistics and Transportation (CIRRELT), succursale centre-ville, Montreal, H3C 3J7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: El Hachemi, N., Interuniversity Research Centre on Enterprise Networks, Logistics and Transportation (CIRRELT), succursale centre-ville, Montreal, H3C 3J7, Canada; Gendreau, M., Interuniversity Research Centre on Enterprise Networks, Logistics and Transportation (CIRRELT), succursale centre-ville, Montreal, H3C 3J7, Canada; Rousseau, L.-M., Interuniversity Research Centre on Enterprise Networks, Logistics and Transportation (CIRRELT), succursale centre-ville, Montreal, H3C 3J7, Canada
Abstract: Scheduling problems in the forest industry have received significant attention in the recent years and have contributed many challenging applications for optimization technologies. This paper proposes a solution method based on constraint programming and mathematical programming for a log-truck scheduling problem. The problem consists of scheduling the transportation of logs between forest areas and woodmills, as well as routing the fleet of vehicles to satisfy these transportation requests. The objective is to minimize the total cost of non-productive activities such as waiting time of trucks and forest log-loaders and the empty driven distance of vehicles. We propose a constraint programming model to address the combined scheduling and routing problem and an integer programming model to deal with the optimization of deadheads. © 2008 Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Index Keywords: Constrained optimization; Forestry; Mathematical models; Mathematical programming; Scheduling; Forest log-loaders; Log-truck scheduling; Woodmills; Problem solving; Forestry; Problem Solving; Scheduling

Authors: Parragh S.N., Doerner K.F., Hartl R.F.
Title: A survey on pickup and delivery problems: Part II: Transportation between pickup and delivery locations
Affiliations: Institut für Betriebswirtschaftslehre, Universität Wien, Brünnerstr. 72, 1210 Wien, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Parragh, S.N., Institut für Betriebswirtschaftslehre, Universität Wien, Brünnerstr. 72, 1210 Wien, Austria; Doerner, K.F., Institut für Betriebswirtschaftslehre, Universität Wien, Brünnerstr. 72, 1210 Wien, Austria; Hartl, R.F., Institut für Betriebswirtschaftslehre, Universität Wien, Brünnerstr. 72, 1210 Wien, Austria
Abstract: This paper is the second part of a comprehensive survey on routing problems involving pickups and deliveries. Basically, two problem classes can be distinguished. The first part dealt with the transportation of goods from the depot to linehaul customers and from backhaul customers to the depot. The second part now considers all those problems where goods are transported between pickup and delivery locations, denoted as Vehicle Routing Problems with Pickups and Deliveries (VRPPD). These are the Pickup and Delivery Vehicle Routing Problem (PDVRP - unpaired pickup and delivery points), the classical Pickup and Delivery Problem (PDP - paired pickup and delivery points), and the Dial-A-Ride Problem (DARP - passenger transportation between paired pickup and delivery points and user inconvenience taken into consideration). Single as well as multi vehicle mathematical problem formulations for all three VRPPD types are given, and the respective exact, heuristic, and metaheuristic solution methods are discussed. © Wirtschaftsuniversität Wien, Austria 2008.
Author Keywords: Dial-a-ride problem; Pick up and delivery problem; Pickup and delivery vehicle routing; Survey; Transportation

Authors: Cordeau J.-F., Laporte G., Ropke S.
Title: Recent models and algorithms for one-to-one pickup and delivery problems
Source title: Operations Research/ Computer Science Interfaces Series
Affiliations: Canada Research Chair in Logistics and Transportation, HEC Montréal, 3000, chemin de la Côte-Sainte-Catherine, Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Cordeau, J.-F., Canada Research Chair in Logistics and Transportation, HEC Montréal, 3000, chemin de la Côte-Sainte-Catherine, Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada; Laporte, G., Canada Research Chair in Logistics and Transportation, HEC Montréal, 3000, chemin de la Côte-Sainte-Catherine, Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada; Ropke, S., Canada Research Chair in Logistics and Transportation, HEC Montréal, 3000, chemin de la Côte-Sainte-Catherine, Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada
Abstract: In one-to-one Pickup and Delivery Problems (PDPs), the aim is to design a set of least cost vehicle routes starting and ending at a common depot in order to satisfy a set of pickup and delivery requests between location pairs, subject to side constraints. Each request originates at one location and is destined for one other location. These requests apply to the transportation of goods or people, in which case the problem is often called the dial-a-ride problem. In recent years, there have been several significant developments in the area of exact and heuristic algorithms for PDPs. The purpose of this chapter is to report on these developments. It contains two main sections devoted to single vehicle and multi-vehicle problems, respectively. Each section is subdivided into two parts, one on exact algorithms and one on heuristics. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2008.
Author Keywords: Branch-and-cut; Column generation; Dial-a-ride; One-to-one; Pickup and delivery; Tabu search

Title: The dial-a-ride problem: Models and algorithms
Affiliations: Canada Research Department in Logistics and Transportation and GERAD, HEC Montréal, 3000, ch. la Cote-Sainte-Catherine, Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada; Canada Research Department in Distribution Management and GERAD, HEC Montréal, 3000, ch. la Cote-Sainte-Catherine, Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Cordeau, J.-F., Canada Research Department in Logistics and Transportation and GERAD, HEC Montréal, 3000, ch. la Cote-Sainte-Catherine, Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada; Laporte, G., Canada Research Department in Distribution Management and GERAD, HEC Montréal, 3000, ch. la Cote-Sainte-Catherine, Montréal, H3T 2A7, Canada
Abstract: The Dial-a-Ride Problem (DARP) consists of designing vehicle routes and schedules for n users who specify pickup and delivery requests between origins and destinations. The aim is to plan a set of m minimum cost vehicle routes capable of accommodating as many users as possible, under a set of constraints. The most common example arises in door-to-door transportation for elderly or disabled people. The purpose of this article is to review the scientific literature on the DARP. The main features of the problem are described and a summary of the most important models and algorithms is provided. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2007.
Author Keywords: Dial-a-ride problem; Static and dynamic pickup and delivery problems; Survey
